user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
  /* Do not use sysctl() function on GNU/Linux even if
     sysctl() is available */
#ifndef __linux__
#ifdef HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* Darwin: The number of available logical CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.logicalcpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* FreeBSD: The number of online CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("kern.smp.cpus", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* Darwin: The current number of CPUs available to run threads */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.activecpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* OpenBSD, NetBSD: The number of online CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.ncpuonline", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* Darwin: The old/alternative name for "hw.activecpu" */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.availcpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME */
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCTL) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_CTL_HW) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_HW_NCPUONLINE)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* OpenBSD, NetBSD: The number of online CPUs */
    int mib[2] = {CTL_HW, HW_NCPUONLINE};
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    if ((0 != sysctl (mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTL && HAS_DECL_CTL_HW && HAS_DECL_HW_NCPUONLINE */
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCTL) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_CTL_HW) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_HW_AVAILCPU)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Darwin: The MIB name for "hw.activecpu" */
    int mib[2] = {CTL_HW, HW_AVAILCPU};
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    if ((0 != sysctl (mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTL && HAS_DECL_CTL_HW && HAS_DECL_HW_AVAILCPU */
#endif /* ! __linux__ */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected all code fragments that are conditionally compiled or conditionally executed and therefore warrant investigation for potential unreachable code: the entire block excluded on __linux__ (which may render a large portion of the function uncompiled), each of the alternative platform/API blocks (the multiple sysctlbyname() if-blocks and the two sysctl() MIB blocks guarded by different feature macros), and the final early-return check. These fragments can be unreachable either because preprocessor conditions exclude them for some builds, or because the layered if (0 >= ret) guards can make later alternative branches never executed in particular executions/configurations — both situations need verification against MISRA Rule 2.1.

Other parts of the function were not included because they are simple, trivially reachable constructs or are necessary control points rather than obviously dead code: the initialization (int ret = -1;), the final return ret;, and the repeated runtime-if guards themselves are not provably unreachable statically without further build/configuration context. The listed fragments cover the code areas that require inspection to determine whether any code is truly unreachable in the project configuration(s).
